## Conversation that answers the provided questions:
**User:**
I've been looking into Verus and I'm curious about staking. What is staking, and how can I participate in it on the Verus blockchain?

**AI Assistant:**
Staking is a way to secure the Verus network by using your Verus holdings. Anyone can participate in staking, regardless of the amount of Verus coins they hold. In Verus, staking is done with UTXOs (unspent transaction outputs), and a larger UTXO has a higher chance of winning a block. This is a great way to contribute to the security of the network and earn some rewards in the process. Do you have any further questions about staking on Verus?

**User:**
That makes sense. I've heard of solo staking and pool staking, what's the difference between them?

**AI Assistant:**
Solo staking involves staking with your own wallet and node, where you either win a full block or nothing. Pool staking, on the other hand, involves joining a pool of stakeholders, where the rewards are shared among the pool members. There are two types of pool staking: non-custodial staking pools, where you keep control of your funds, and custodial staking pools, where you trust a pool operator with your funds. So, it really depends on your personal preference and risk tolerance.

**User:**
I think I'll try solo staking. What are the rules to start solo staking on Verus?

**AI Assistant:**
To start solo staking on Verus, you need to:

1. Have your wallet running
2. Run a full node (native mode in Verus Desktop)
3. Enable staking
4. Have a UTXO that is eligible for staking after 150 blocks
5. Have a minimum of 0.00000001 VRSC in your wallet

Make sure you follow these steps and you'll be set up for solo staking on Verus. If you have any more questions or need further assistance, feel free to ask!
What is staking, and how can I participate in it on the Verus blockchain?

Staking is a way to secure the Verus network by using your Verus holdings. Anyone can participate in staking, regardless of the amount of Verus coins they hold. In Verus, staking is done with UTXOs (unspent transaction outputs), and a larger UTXO has a higher chance of winning a block.

# Staking

Staking is accessible for everyone. Use Verus holdings to secure the network. It does not matter how much $VRSC you have, there are no minimum requirements to start staking.

On the Verus blockchain UTXOs (unspent transaction outputs) are staking, not balances. A large UTXO has more chances of winning a block than a small UTXO. [What is a UTXO?](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xJ0UYZ9hDos)

## Solo staking
There are a few rules you need to know before you can start staking.

| Rules | 
| :-----|
| Wallet Running | 
| Full Node Required (native mode in Verus Desktop) | 
| Staking Enabled | 
| UTXO Eligible After 150 Blocks | 
| Minimum of 0.00000001 VRSC in Wallet |

With solo staking you either win a full block or you win nothing.

::: warning Need help with staking? 💰
[Join the Verus Discord #staking channel. The community is happy to assist!](https://www.verus.io/discord). 
:::

## Pool staking
There are two ways to do pool staking with Verus. One is keeping control over your funds in combination with VerusID, the other is sending your coins to a pool operator and trusting your funds with them.

A non-custodial staking pool: [Synergy Pool](https://synergopool.io)
What is the difference between solo staking and pool staking?

Solo staking involves staking with your own wallet and node, where you either win a full block or nothing. Pool staking, on the other hand, involves joining a pool of stakeholders, where the rewards are shared among the pool members. There are two types of pool staking: non-custodial staking pools, where you keep control of your funds, and custodial staking pools, where you trust a pool operator with your funds.

# Staking

Staking is accessible for everyone. Use Verus holdings to secure the network. It does not matter how much $VRSC you have, there are no minimum requirements to start staking.

On the Verus blockchain UTXOs (unspent transaction outputs) are staking, not balances. A large UTXO has more chances of winning a block than a small UTXO. [What is a UTXO?](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xJ0UYZ9hDos)
